p: Red thyme, common thyme, oregano, and cinnamon have showed the best antimicrobial potential in the qualitative assay against the field isolates of S. suis, including the European reference strain P1/7. According to the classification proposed by Lv et al. ( 2011), red thyme, common thyme, and oregano would have a strong activity (inhibition zone ≥20 mm) and cinnamon, a moderate one (inhibition zone between 12 and 20 mm). These EOs have also shown a good antimicrobial activity against a wide variety of microbial pathogens involved in different clinical processes of both humans and animals, including other Streptococcus species (Fabio, Cermelli, Fabio, Nicoletti, & Quaglio, 2007; Galvão et al., 2012; Sfeir et al., 2013). Taking into account these preliminary results, red thyme, common thyme, oregano, and cinnamon essential oils were selected for the quantitative study.
